It blooms from late spring to early summer, and the ideal location for it is in a sunny spot with fertile soil. The flowers are followed by small decorative red-black berries. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5005,"attracts":[],"care_level":null,"common_name":"parrot's beak","description":"Parrot's beak (Lotus berthelotii) is a flowering perennial native to parts of Africa, Spain, and the Canary Islands. A hardy, low maintenance plant, it grows in full sun to partial shade, and only needs light watering. The stunning blooms are its most attractive feature, looking like the beak of a parrot and ranging from yellow, orange, white to deep red-purple. The flowers form in clusters on curving stems above striking fern-like foliage. Parrot's beak is excellent for rock or gravel gardens and cottage gardens. Multiplying easily by self-seeding, the flower also works well for naturalized landscapes and windbreaks.","family":"Fabaceae","flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":[],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Canary Islands"],"other_name":["coral gem","pelican's beak","lotus vine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pest resistant"," Disease resistant"," Deer resistant"," Drought resistant"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Greenwood Cuttings"],"pruning_month":["March","April","August"],"scientific_name":["Lotus berthelotii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":null}}

Its delicate, bell-shaped flowers come in a range of vibrant colors, from purple, blue, pink, white, and yellow. The lupine requires full sun and well-drained soil to thrive, and it can reach heights of up to two feet. Its long taproot system excels in pollinating and providing good aeration for the soil, which make it a great choice for landscape and vegetable gardens. Its flowers provide an abundance of nectar for a variety of birds and insects. Lupine is also a great choice for attracting butterflies, making it a stunning addition to any garden!","family":"Fabaceae","flower_color":"White, red, pink, yellow, blue, purple or bicolor","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green","gray","gray"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean region","Middle East","North Africa","Southwestern Asia","Europe"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting","Division","Layering Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March","April","May","June","July"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus hybrida"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5014,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"catchfly","description":"Catchfly (Lychnis coronaria) is a beautiful flowering plant with a unique look. The stems are tall yet wiry, and each stem is topped with a cluster of petite, magenta-pink flowers. There are green, saw-toothed leaves along the stem, and the tissue between the veins of the leaves is sticky. This stickiness is how the catchfly got its name, as it’s said to “catch” small insects in its sap. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5041,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"gooseneck loosestrife","description":"Gooseneck loosestrife (Lysimachia clethroides) is an attractive and unusual perennial. Growing up to thirty inches tall, the plant bears small white flowers in the shape of a ringing bell. It's attractive foliage features heart-shaped leaves and stems that crawl along the ground. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5104,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"magnolia","description":"Magnolia wieseneri is an evergreen shrub or small tree native to Southeast Asia that can grow up to 10 metres tall.

It grows to about 3-5 feet in height and has persistent, variegated green and white leaves. The long, tuberous, starchy roots vary in colour from white to yellow or even purple. Bitter Cassava makes a good substitute for potatoes in many dishes and can be roasted, mashed, or boiled and used in soups, stews, and curries. Its leaves can also be eaten. As its name implies, this variety of cassava is bitter due to increased levels of toxic cyanogenic glucosides. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5165,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_level":null,"common_name":"climbing milkweed","description":"Climbing milkweed (Matelea decipiens) is a fast-growing perennial vine with dark green, 3- to 5-lobed leaves. In spring and summer, clusters of white, star-shaped flowers appear on the vine. These flowers attract bees, butterflies, and other pollinators, making this plant an ideal choice for a wildlife garden.
